title: Russia violated whistleblower Magnitsky’s human rights, says court
text:
The interior of the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, France | Frederick Florin/AFP via Getty Images Russia violated whistleblower Magnitsky’s human rights, says court Judges in Strasbourg say the auditor, who died in jail in 2009, had been ill-treated in prison.

Europe's top human rights court has condemned Russia for multiple violations in the case of prominent whistleblower Sergei Magnitsky.

Magnitsky, an auditor who uncovered a $230 million fraud scheme by Russian tax officials and was subsequently arrested, died aged 37 while in pre-trial detention in 2009 after his repeated requests for medical help were denied.

On Tuesday, the European Court of Human Rights ruled that the conditions of his detention had breached Magnitsky's basic rights and ordered Russia to pay €34,000 to his widow and his mother.

Judges at the Strasbourg-based court found that Magnitsky had been mistreated by prison guards. In their verdict, they added that the medical care Magnitsky received "had been inadequate and had led to his death."

Besides insufficient medical care and ill treatment, the court said that the length of his detention — which lasted just under a year from his arrest to his death — was unjustified, that he was held in severely overcrowded conditions, and that Russian authorities failed to carry out an "effective investigation" into allegations of mistreatment and and medical negligence.

The court also ruled that the posthumous trial, which resulted in Magnitsky's conviction over tax evasion in 2013, breached the European Convention on Human Rights due to its "inherent unfairness." The judges rejected a complaint that Magnitsky's arrest and detention had been "ill-founded," however, arguing that there had been enough evidence to suspect him of tax evasion.

Magnitsky's death in 2009 sparked an outcry. The U.S. in 2012 implemented the Magnitsky Act, a law enabling Washington to freeze assets and block visas of Russian officials thought to be involved in human rights violations.

The Magnitsky Act was spearheaded by Bill Browder, the manager of an investment fund that Magnitsky advised. Browder on Tuesday called the Strasbourg court's ruling a "resounding victory."

Russia's Interfax news agency reported that the country's justice ministry would consider whether to appeal within the next three months.
description: Judges in Strasbourg say the auditor, who died in jail in 2009, had been ill-treated in prison.
